questions.question: Consolidated financial statements are required when a parent company has:

options.A: At least 20% ownership of another entity
options.B: A controlling financial interest in another entity
options.D: An investment in another entity's debt securities

questions.explanation: Consolidation is required when a parent has a controlling financial interest in a subsidiary. Control is generally evidenced by ownership of more than 50% of voting shares or through variable interest entity (VIE) relationships.
questions.tip: Control = consolidation. Significant influence = equity method.

questions.question: Under the voting interest model, control is generally presumed when a parent owns:

options.B: More than 50% of voting shares

questions.explanation: Under the voting interest model, a parent is presumed to have control when it owns more than 50% of the voting shares (majority ownership).
questions.tip: >50% voting shares = control under voting interest model.

questions.question: In the consolidation process, the parent's investment in subsidiary account is eliminated against:

options.B: The subsidiary's equity accounts

questions.explanation: The investment in subsidiary account on the parent's books is eliminated against the subsidiary's equity accounts (common stock, APIC, retained earnings) to avoid double-counting.
questions.tip: Investment ↔ Sub's equity = eliminated in consolidation.

questions.question: Intercompany transactions are eliminated in consolidation because:

options.B: The consolidated entity cannot transact with itself

questions.explanation: Intercompany transactions are eliminated because consolidated financial statements present the economic entity as a single unit. An entity cannot sell to itself or owe money to itself.
questions.tip: Consolidated entity = one unit, can't transact with itself.

questions.question: Parent sells inventory to Subsidiary for $100,000 (cost $70,000). At year-end, 40% of the inventory remains unsold. What is the unrealized intercompany profit to eliminate?
questions.explanation: Total profit = $100,000 - $70,000 = $30,000. Unrealized profit (in ending inventory) = $30,000 × 40% = $12,000. The $18,000 on sold inventory is realized.
questions.tip: Unrealized profit = Total profit × % still in inventory.

questions.question: In a downstream sale of inventory from parent to subsidiary, 100% of unrealized profit is eliminated against:

options.B: The parent's share of consolidated net income

questions.explanation: In downstream sales (parent to sub), the parent made the sale, so 100% of unrealized profit is eliminated against the parent's (controlling) share of consolidated income. NCI is unaffected.
questions.tip: Downstream = parent sold, parent absorbs 100% of unrealized profit.

questions.question: In an upstream sale from a 70%-owned subsidiary to the parent, unrealized profit is eliminated:

options.B: 70% against controlling interest, 30% against NCI

questions.explanation: In upstream sales (sub to parent), the subsidiary made the profit. Unrealized profit is allocated proportionally: 70% against controlling interest and 30% against noncontrolling interest.
questions.tip: Upstream = sub sold, profit split by ownership %.

questions.question: On consolidated financial statements, noncontrolling interest is presented as:

options.B: A component of equity, separate from parent's equity

questions.explanation: Noncontrolling interest is presented in the equity section of the consolidated balance sheet, separately from the parent's stockholders' equity.
questions.tip: NCI = equity, shown separately from parent's equity.

questions.question: Parent owns 80% of Sub. At acquisition, Sub's equity was $500,000 and NCI was recorded at fair value of $130,000. In Year 1, Sub earned $100,000 and paid $20,000 dividends. What is NCI at year-end?
questions.explanation: Beginning NCI: $130,000. NCI share of income (20%): $20,000. NCI share of dividends (20%): ($4,000). Ending NCI: $130,000 + $20,000 - $4,000 = $146,000.
questions.tip: NCI = Beginning + NCI% of income - NCI% of dividends.

questions.question: Parent sells equipment to Subsidiary for $80,000 (NBV $50,000). The equipment has a 5-year remaining life. What is the net adjustment to consolidated depreciation expense for Year 1?

options.B: Decrease of $6,000

questions.explanation: Unrealized gain = $80,000 - $50,000 = $30,000. Sub depreciates at $80,000/5 = $16,000. Correct depreciation = $50,000/5 = $10,000. Adjustment: reduce depreciation by $6,000 ($16,000 - $10,000).
questions.tip: Intercompany fixed asset: reduce depreciation to realize gain over life.

questions.question: When a subsidiary purchases bonds of the parent from a third party, the consolidated entity treats this as:

options.B: A constructive retirement of debt

questions.explanation: When one member of a consolidated group holds bonds issued by another member, the bonds are considered constructively retired from the consolidated entity's perspective. The intercompany bond investment and payable are eliminated.
questions.tip: Affiliate buys affiliate's bonds = constructive retirement.

questions.question: Parent has bonds payable with carrying value of $485,000. Subsidiary purchases these bonds from outsiders for $470,000. What is the gain/loss on constructive retirement?

options.B: Gain of $15,000

questions.explanation: Constructive retirement gain/loss = Carrying value of debt - Purchase price = $485,000 - $470,000 = $15,000 gain. The entity effectively retired debt for less than its carrying amount.
questions.tip: Constructive gain = Debt carrying value - Price paid by affiliate.

questions.question: Dividends paid by a subsidiary to the parent are:

options.A: Reported as dividend income on the consolidated income statement
options.B: Eliminated in consolidation

questions.explanation: Intercompany dividends are eliminated in consolidation. The parent's dividend income and the subsidiary's dividends declared offset each other, preventing double-counting.
questions.tip: Intercompany dividends = eliminated (money moving within the entity).

questions.question: A variable interest entity (VIE) must be consolidated by:

options.A: The entity with the largest investment
options.B: The primary beneficiary
options.D: No entity; VIEs are never consolidated

questions.explanation: A VIE must be consolidated by its primary beneficiary—the entity that has both (1) power to direct activities that most significantly impact the VIE's economic performance and (2) obligation to absorb losses or right to receive benefits.
questions.tip: VIE consolidation: primary beneficiary (power + economics).

questions.question: Which is a characteristic of a variable interest entity (VIE)?

options.A: More than 50% voting control by one entity
options.B: Insufficient equity investment at risk to finance activities without additional support

questions.explanation: A VIE typically has insufficient equity at risk to finance its activities without additional subordinated financial support from other parties. Traditional voting control analysis doesn't apply.
questions.tip: VIE = insufficient equity at risk or equity lacks characteristics.

questions.question: On the consolidated income statement, a subsidiary's revenues and expenses are:

options.A: Shown as a single equity income line item
options.B: Included line-by-line (100%) with NCI deducted at the bottom
options.C: Included only to the extent of parent's ownership percentage

questions.explanation: In consolidation, 100% of the subsidiary's revenues and expenses are combined with the parent's line-by-line. Net income attributable to NCI is then deducted to arrive at net income attributable to controlling interest.
questions.tip: Consolidation: 100% inclusion, NCI share deducted at bottom.

questions.question: P Corp owns 75% of S Corp. Consolidated net income is $400,000. S Corp earned $100,000 and declared $40,000 dividends. What is the net income attributable to controlling interest?
questions.explanation: NCI's share of S's income = 25% × $100,000 = $25,000. Net income to controlling interest = $400,000 - $25,000 = $375,000. Dividends don't affect income calculation.
questions.tip: Controlling interest NI = Consolidated NI - NCI share of sub income.

questions.question: When a subsidiary is acquired mid-year, the consolidated income statement includes:

options.B: Subsidiary's results only from acquisition date forward
options.C: Subsidiary's results restated as if acquired January 1
options.D: No subsidiary results until the following year

questions.explanation: The consolidated income statement includes the subsidiary's revenues and expenses only from the acquisition date forward. Pre-acquisition results belong to the prior owners.
questions.tip: Mid-year acquisition: only post-acquisition results consolidated.

questions.question: At acquisition, a subsidiary's equipment had book value $200,000 and fair value $260,000 (remaining life 6 years). In Year 3 of consolidation, what is the adjustment to depreciation expense?

options.B: Increase of $60,000

questions.explanation: FV adjustment = $260,000 - $200,000 = $60,000 over 6 years = $10,000/year additional depreciation. Each year (including Year 3), depreciation is increased by $10,000.
questions.tip: FV adjustments create additional depreciation/amortization.

questions.question: Goodwill in a consolidated entity is tested for impairment at:

options.B: The reporting unit level

questions.explanation: Goodwill is tested for impairment at the reporting unit level. A reporting unit is an operating segment or one level below, to which goodwill is assigned.
questions.tip: Goodwill impairment: reporting unit level.

questions.question: A reporting unit has a carrying amount of $5,000,000 including goodwill of $800,000. Fair value of the reporting unit is $4,500,000. What is the goodwill impairment loss?
questions.explanation: Impairment = Carrying amount - Fair value = $5,000,000 - $4,500,000 = $500,000. This is less than total goodwill ($800,000), so impairment is $500,000.
questions.tip: Goodwill impairment = excess of carrying value over FV (limited to goodwill balance).

questions.question: When a parent purchases additional shares from noncontrolling shareholders (maintaining control), the difference between price paid and NCI book value is recorded as:

options.B: Gain or loss in earnings

questions.explanation: When a parent acquires NCI shares while maintaining control, it's an equity transaction. The difference between consideration paid and NCI's carrying value is adjusted against the parent's equity (typically APIC).
questions.tip: Buying NCI (control maintained) = equity transaction, no gain/loss.

questions.question: When a parent sells some subsidiary shares but retains control, the transaction is accounted for as:

options.B: An equity transaction with no gain/loss
options.D: A change from consolidation to equity method

questions.explanation: When a parent sells shares but retains control, it's an equity transaction—the proceeds increase NCI and any difference from carrying value adjusts parent's equity. No gain/loss is recognized.
questions.tip: Selling sub shares (keeping control) = equity transaction.

questions.question: When a parent loses control of a subsidiary, the parent:

options.A: Continues consolidating until all shares are sold
options.B: Recognizes a gain or loss on deconsolidation
options.C: Restates prior periods as if control was never held
options.D: Reports loss of control as a discontinued operation always

questions.explanation: When control is lost, the subsidiary is deconsolidated. The parent recognizes a gain or loss equal to the difference between fair value of consideration received plus any retained interest, minus the carrying amount of the subsidiary's net assets.
questions.tip: Loss of control = deconsolidation + gain/loss recognition.

questions.question: After losing control of a former subsidiary, any retained investment is measured at:

options.B: The proportionate share of book value

questions.explanation: When control is lost, any retained investment in the former subsidiary is remeasured to fair value at the deconsolidation date. This fair value becomes the initial carrying amount under the new accounting method (equity method or fair value).
questions.tip: Retained interest after deconsolidation = fair value on that date.

questions.question: P owns 90% of S. P's total assets are $800,000 (including Investment in S of $270,000). S's total assets are $350,000. What are consolidated total assets (ignoring eliminations other than investment)?
questions.explanation: P's assets excluding investment: $800,000 - $270,000 = $530,000. Add 100% of S's assets: $530,000 + $350,000 = $880,000. The investment is eliminated and replaced with S's actual assets.
questions.tip: Consolidated assets = P assets - Investment + 100% S assets.

questions.question: An intercompany loan from parent to subsidiary appears on consolidated financial statements as:

options.A: A receivable and payable that net to zero
options.B: Eliminated entirely

questions.explanation: Intercompany receivables and payables are eliminated in consolidation because the consolidated entity cannot owe money to itself.
questions.tip: Intercompany loans = eliminated (entity can't owe itself).

questions.question: When push-down accounting is elected, the subsidiary's separate financial statements:

options.B: Reflect the new basis from the acquisition (fair values and goodwill)

questions.explanation: Push-down accounting allows the subsidiary to record the new basis established by the acquirer in its own separate financial statements, including fair value adjustments and goodwill.
questions.tip: Push-down: sub's books reflect acquisition fair values.

questions.question: In years subsequent to acquisition, the consolidation workpaper entry affecting beginning retained earnings represents:

options.B: Cumulative effects of prior years' eliminations
options.D: Dividends declared in the current year

questions.explanation: In subsequent years, adjustments to beginning retained earnings represent the cumulative effect of prior years' eliminations that affected income (e.g., unrealized profits, depreciation of fair value adjustments).
questions.tip: Beginning RE adjustment = cumulative prior eliminations.

questions.question: When calculating NCI in a subsidiary with preferred stock outstanding, the preferred stock:

options.B: Is allocated entirely to controlling interest
options.C: Must be considered in allocating equity to NCI
options.D: Converts to common stock for consolidation

questions.explanation: Subsidiary preferred stock held by outsiders is part of NCI. The preferred stock's claims (par value, accumulated dividends) must be allocated to NCI before allocating common equity interests.
questions.tip: Sub's preferred held by outsiders = part of NCI.

questions.question: P owns 80% of S, and S owns 70% of T. What is P's effective ownership interest in T?
questions.explanation: Indirect ownership = P's % of S × S's % of T = 80% × 70% = 56%. P effectively owns 56% of T through its investment in S.
questions.tip: Indirect ownership = multiply the ownership percentages.

questions.question: Management fees charged by a parent to its subsidiary are:

options.A: Reported as service revenue on consolidated statements
options.B: Eliminated in consolidation
options.C: Reported as a reduction of operating expenses

questions.explanation: Intercompany management fees are eliminated because they represent transactions within the consolidated entity. The fee income and expense offset each other.
questions.tip: All intercompany transactions eliminated—services included.

questions.question: When an investor acquires additional shares and moves from significant influence (equity method) to control:

options.B: Remeasure the previously held interest to fair value and begin consolidation
options.C: Account for the new shares only using the acquisition method
options.D: Retroactively restate prior periods as consolidated

questions.explanation: This is a step acquisition achieving control. The previously held equity method investment is remeasured to acquisition-date fair value (with gain/loss in earnings), and full consolidation begins.
questions.tip: Equity method → control = remeasure old investment to FV.

questions.question: P paid $600,000 for 100% of S when S had common stock of $200,000, APIC of $150,000, and retained earnings of $100,000. FV of net assets equaled book value. What is the goodwill eliminated in the consolidation entry?
questions.explanation: S's book value (= FV) of net assets = $200,000 + $150,000 + $100,000 = $450,000. Goodwill = Purchase price - FV of net assets = $600,000 - $450,000 = $150,000.
questions.tip: Goodwill = Price - FV of net assets acquired.

questions.question: When a parent acquires a subsidiary by issuing common stock, the consolidated APIC reflects:

options.A: The sum of parent and subsidiary APIC
options.B: Only the parent's APIC (subsidiary APIC is eliminated)

questions.explanation: In consolidation, the subsidiary's equity accounts (including APIC) are eliminated against the investment. The consolidated APIC reflects only the parent's APIC, which includes any increase from shares issued in the acquisition.
questions.tip: Consolidated APIC = parent's APIC only (sub's is eliminated).

questions.question: If a subsidiary reports a net loss, the noncontrolling interest:

options.B: Absorbs its proportionate share of the loss
options.C: Is not affected by subsidiary losses

questions.explanation: NCI absorbs its proportionate share of subsidiary losses, even if this results in a deficit NCI balance. Losses are allocated based on ownership percentage.
questions.tip: NCI shares in losses proportionately (can go negative).

questions.question: Noncontrolling interest's share of a subsidiary's other comprehensive income (OCI) is:

options.A: Allocated to NCI based on ownership percentage
options.B: Always allocated 100% to controlling interest
options.C: Not reported in consolidated financial statements

questions.explanation: NCI shares proportionately in the subsidiary's comprehensive income, including OCI items. The consolidated statement of comprehensive income shows NCI's share of both net income and OCI.
questions.tip: NCI gets proportionate share of net income AND OCI.

questions.question: When a subsidiary holds shares of its parent company, the consolidated financial statements treat these shares as:

options.B: Treasury stock

questions.explanation: Parent shares held by a consolidated subsidiary are treated as treasury stock in the consolidated financial statements, reducing consolidated equity.
questions.tip: Sub holding parent's stock = treasury stock in consolidation.

questions.question: When a subsidiary has a different fiscal year-end than the parent, consolidation is based on:

options.A: The subsidiary's fiscal year with no adjustment
options.B: Subsidiary financial statements with year-end within 3 months of parent's, or additional financial information

questions.explanation: If the subsidiary's year-end is within 3 months of the parent's, its fiscal year results may be used. Otherwise, the subsidiary must prepare additional financial information aligned with the parent's year-end.
questions.tip: Different year-ends: use if within 3 months, otherwise get aligned data.

questions.question: Combined financial statements differ from consolidated financial statements in that combined statements:

options.B: Present commonly controlled entities without a parent-subsidiary relationship

questions.explanation: Combined financial statements present entities under common control (e.g., brother-sister companies) that don't have a parent-subsidiary relationship. There's no elimination of a parent's investment account.
questions.tip: Combined = common control without parent-sub relationship.
